content.description: This climb is dedicated to our beloved friend and partner Andrew Berge, a great man of many talents! Keep climbing high above the anchor and we’ll meet you up above the clouds brotha ! RIP 5/13/21... Scramble up and left of the belay on a low-angled ramp before clipping the first bolt in a short corner (25 ft.) The route traverses up and right to a good stance before ascending a vertical face. The finish is a tad bit exciting as you climb above the void, moving carefully to avoid the reverse rocket ride.
content.protection: 5 Bolts to chain anchor. It is possible to top out on the formation where the Original Bolts placed by Ken Stanton (25 yrs. old) are in place.  These bolts were installed during the FA of a devious overhanging corner/crack system just around the arête to the right of Rocket Ride.
content.location: The left most route on the west face of Hailstone Rock. Belay directly beneath the anchor, 30 feet up the slope from the tree which shades the start of Hail Fire and Close Encounters. The anchor is a Fixe chain/ring lower off.

climbs.name: Hailstone Crack
climbs.fa: Ken Stanton, Jack Fisher, Joanie Harris, 1978

content.description: Hailstone Crack is believed to be the first route climbed at Hailstone Rock.  But for the approach this climb would be considered a classic crack in an area not known for such. This surprisingly steep route features straight in hands, fist, and some wider sized sections of climbing with some nice edges, stems, and features on the surrounding face.
content.protection: A few small, medium, and larger (#2, #3, and maybe one #4 sized units). No Bolts or fixed gear. Finishes on ledge adjacent to bolted anchors.
content.location: This route is 15 feet to the right of Close Encounters route base.

content.description: This is one of the longer face climbs in the park with a distinct crux just before the anchor. Mark Howe was inspirational in sharing his knowledge of Hailstone and was the first to explore variations of this route in the mid -1990's.
content.protection: Pass 7 bolts to clip the chain anchor at the top of the formation.
content.location: As one approaches the crag from the trail below Hailstone Rock this is the first fully bolted route on the right side (lowest point) of the western face. This route shares the start of the Doc's Holiday gully route, but stays a few feet left of the arête after the start. Belay from a small flat area of the trail slightly right of the line of bolts above. The first bolt is about 25 feet up the low angled face.

content.description: This climb features some steep face climbing at the start before entering and surmounting a strenuous roof. Gain a good stance above the bulge, and with the crux behind you, enjoy a moderate cruise to the anchors.  It's possible to top out on the formation and enjoy the spacious summit plateau from here.
content.location: Shares the first bolt of the Close Encounters route, climbing left after clipping and gain a stance on a small ledge at the start of the hard climbing.

content.description: This is a four bolt variation start of Coroner, about 20 ft right. Pulls an exciting bulge. This variation is called "ETI" (Extra Terrestrial Intelligence) 5.10b PG and shares the finish of "Coroner".
Lichen covered crack, rarely climbed, so be careful of loose rock.
content.location: Crack is on the East face of Hailstone Rock

content.description: Doppelganger is located on the western arête of "Hole in the Wall" Rock. The climbing starts out by climbing past a couple bolts and moving up a stemming trough which culminates on a ledge.  A steeper section is encountered before clipping the rings at the rim of the formation. A good warm up. Other lines have been top roped here. On the back side of the arch is a 4th class access to the top of Hole in the Wall which is a great spot for a picnic or to take in the views. There are several anchors on the summit set well back from the cliff edge (Bring very long slings.)
content.location: This climb is located about 100 feet west of the base of Hailstone Arête at the foot of the western side of Hole in the Wall Rock.

content.description: This route ascends a wide gully on the south buttress of Hailstone Rock.  After clipping the first bolt (shared with Hailstone Arete route) veer off right towards the base of a steep gully Ascend up through  a series of broken tiered ledges to the bolted anchor shared with Hailstone Arete.  A big shout out and thanks to Alex Isabeau, Mojo, and others who discovered and climbed many obscure routes throughout MSH !
content.protection: Shares the start and first bolt of Hailstone arête route. After that small to medium gear placements can be used to protect the reminder of the route. Shares an anchor with the Hailstone Arete route.
content.location: This route starts at the base of steep gully approx. 20 feet right of the Hailstone arête route base.

content.description: Starts with some lesser quality stone which improves as you move up the dihedral. Stemming and face moves protected by bolts.  The crux is where the corner pinches off below a steep headwall. This route features very good movement, especially on the upper section. Despite the somewhat grim sounding route name the protection is good, and a call to the Coroner should in most cases not be necessary if taking on the lead of this route.
content.location: 10-12 feet right of Hailstone Crack route. Shares anchor with Hailstone Arete

content.description: Starts off by climbing an exposed bouldery section onto a ledge and a small stemming corner. After clipping a couple of bolts move left out of the corner into a steep section. Here the crux is a sustained series of somewhat ponderous moves up and into a second corner system and a rest. The climbing is sustained and steep above the crux on rock that's very granite-like. The angle eases off before the anchor is reached, near the site of occasional bird encounters.
content.location: Belay on a flat ledge behind an obvious shady tree.  Shares start with the climb "Hail Fire".
